comments: Define the sequence L(a_0,a_1) by a_{n+2} is the greatest integer such that a_{n+2}/a_{n+1}<a_{n+1}/a_n for n >= 0. This is L(1,9).For n>=2, a(n) equals the permanent of the (n-1)X(n-1) tridiagonal matrix with 9's along the main diagonal, and i's along the superdiagonal and the subdiagonal (i is the imaginary unit). - John M. Campbell, Jul 08 2011For n>=1, a(n) equals the number of 01-avoiding words of length n-1 on alphabet {0,1,...,8}. - _Milan Janjic_, Jan 25 2015Not to be confused with the Pisot L(1,9) sequence, which is A001019. - _R. J. Mathar_, Feb 13 2016
